Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Porous Tantalum Cementless and Cemented Tibial Components in Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: A total of 145 patients were randomised into two groups

Intervention.evidence: Group 1 received a porous tantalum cementless tibial component, and Group 2 received a cemented conventional tibial component

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial evaluates the clinical outcomes of porous tantalum cementless tibial components versus conventional cemented components in total knee arthroplasty (TKA).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Knee Society Score (KSS) and WOMAC Osteoarthritis Index, measured preoperatively and at 15 days, 6 months, and 5 years postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 145 patients were randomised into two groups

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 5-year follow-up, the mean KSS was 90.4 (95% CI, ±1.6) for Group 1 and 86.5 (95% CI, ±2.4) for Group 2, with an effect size of 3.88 ± 2.87.

Harms.evidence: No significant differences were observed in complications or aseptic loosening between groups.
